history.content:
As a longtime TA for a large course, I can tell you that a greater quantity of a repetitive question does nothing to elicit a faster response, but instead:

  1. Replaces most feelings of sympathy with those of annoyance
  2. Clutters the space, obscuring other potentially important information

Clearly a decision had not been made yet and further announcements from the department were warranted, and I'm not sure 10 posts asking about it changed that fact.

I agree the "chill out" language was in poor taste, though.

======

edit by thomas - my response is in a followup, to permit easier replies

  2. Clutters the space, obscuring other potentially important information

Clearly a decision had not been made yet and further announcements from the department were warranted, and I'm not sure 10 posts asking about it changed that fact.

I agree the "chill out" language was in poor taste, though.

  2. Clutters the space, obscuring other potentially important information

================

Dear Abhijay,


I agree that patronizing students should be banned from the EECS piazza. For example, self-righteous students who believe that they alone have the supreme moral authority to call for other students to be excluded from a community resource should themselves be banned. Just kidding.


But let's be serious.


To all -


I'm a senior now, so I was around when: Southside got shut down because the Amazon store caught on fire; Southside got shut down because of the Milo protests; fires closed down campus in 2017; fires closed down campus in 2018; power outages closed down campus in 2019.


This pandemic really takes the cake.


We've all joked and memed before about how, in each of these crises, it feels like the world is coming to an end - but now, truly, the whole world has come to a halt. All of California is under a lockdown - it is impossible to sit down for a meal with friends, it's forbidden to go to the barber for a haircut, and it's illegal to watch a movie in a theater. And it's not just Berkeley, or just California, it's New York, Washington, Illinois, it's entire countries like Italy. Many students have family and friends who have fallen ill or lost work. We know that people will die. Thousands already have, and we are only in the beginning of the beginning. These are truly unprecedented times, not only for us or the generation above us, but for the entire world, for all of humanity.


I know it is hard to chill out. When I was a freshman, I really despised all those seniors, who, with job offers in hand, glittering resumes and prestigious internships, would tell me to "chill out". When TAs told me to chill out before an exam, it infuriated me. So why do I say to "chill out" now? Because there are some things that are truly outside your control.

The emergence of a novel coronavirus halfway around the world, for which no natural immunity or man-made vaccine exists, is completely out of your control. The impending recession is out of your control. To some degree, the catastrophic failure of the federal government's response is out of your control (please vote this fall, if you are able!). And, mostly, the EECS department's policy is out of your control. You won't get anywhere by stressing - a painful truth, but a truth nonetheless. So chill out.


What I've learned over these four years is that the EECS department actually does care about you. Unlike central campus, which does not seem to care if you live or die, so long as your heirs and assigns pay the bill. Professors care. The grade cap has stayed so low for so long only because they care. Your GSIs care. They work for so hard for so long because they care. Your advisors care. They put out fires you don't see all the time, every edge case, every special circumstance, all the people you don't see who are every bit as much in need and more.


The department - professors, advisors, GSIs, uGSIs - they're just people. If it's hard for you to chill out, consider that how hard it must be chill out when you have a mortgage to pay, rambunctious children to care for, elderly parents to shelter.

Be kind, and wait. Wait for faculty and staff to make sure that they have their own house in order, that their family and friends are ok, healthy, safe. I know how frustrating it is to not hear anything, I really do. They do too. But right now, be kind, be patient, and wait.

Sometimes things just take time.

Please, *chill out and wait for the eecs department to announce.*

Yours truly,

Thomas

children.subject: response is later in thead, thx for tag
shoumik, I want you to think harder about calling for mob justice as a knee-jerk reaction. You're better than this, come on!
i agree. if they're not posting as anon, they need to be named and shamed.
I agree this student went out of line and should be banned from this Piazza if they have nothing helpful to say.

Once again, please stop patronizing the students who are stressed. It is not your place to explain to us how or why this situation is stressful, or how others should feel during this. You yourself noted that when other's told you to "chill out," it infuriated you. Similarly, your language infuriates others.

It does not matter how empathetic you think you are being implicitly. Your explicit words were only contributing to the stress, frustration, and in your own words, infuriation going on right now.

If you wanted to be helpful, you could've posted then about how the EECS department cares about you and how they themselves are working their hardest to make a tough situation fair for everyone. Instead, you were dismissive and clearly caused others to feel worse, as evidence by the support on my post.

The EECS department is toxic as it is. Please don't reinforce that reputation.

I'm not going to bother pointing out the hypocrisy of decrying the toxicity of the EECS department while simultaneously demanding the banning of a specific, single student as a nuclear option, or the insincerity of lambasting somebody as patronizing while speaking down to them, or the dual-faced attack of calling people unhelpful while contributing absolutely nothing more than hot gas, because there's a time and place for that, and it's not this forum right now.

I have no idea how this became a combative conversation. I am honestly confused. Please enjoy egg: 🥚🥚🥚🥚🥚🥚🥚🥚🥚🥚🥚🥚🥚🥚🥚🥚🥚🥚🥚🥚🥚🥚🥚🥚🥚🥚

meanwhile -

~ ~ chilling out and waiting for the eecs department to announce ~ ~

I don't think you should be banned or whatever but you definitely could have phrased it better. If you spammed those last few paragraphs at the bottom of your original response, "what I've learned," "the department," "be kind" I'm sure people would have been more receptive. Spamming "chill out" with nothing else definitely comes off as a more "lol shut up no one cares about you" mood than "I know things are tough right now but be patient". Thanks for this thread though.

That being said I'm currently chilling out and waiting for the eecs department to announce

How is the EECS department toxic in any way? There's so many resources and all the GSIs and advisors are always there ready to help you. Thomas is right in that it takes time for the department to decide and no amount of Piazza posting will change that.

history.content: We do have a post about etiquette on Piazza, @8167. It's hard for the advisors to monitor all the posts, though. If anything seems inappropriate, please email either cs-advising@cs.berkeley.edu or eecs-advising@eecs.berkeley.edu with the posts and we'll look into it.

There's a student spamming patronizing responses to all of the current EECS piazza posts, and marking unresolved posts as resolved.

As a declared CS student, none of those posts relate to me, but I can recognize the disrespectful nature of this students flippant attitude towards other students legitimate concerns. It is in no way helpful to spam "chill out" to other students who are surely panicked about many things right now, including their academic careers. (When was the last time anyone "chilled out" in response to a stranger telling them to do so?) I don't think they should be allowed to contribute further to this piazza.

I recognize there is an abundance of posts on similar topics, but it is the prerogative of the faculty to create a megathread for topics. Until then, greater quantities probably help elicit faster responses. 

Best,

Abhijay
history.subject: Is it possible to ban patronizing students from the EECS piazza?
